body:
- [x] Resolves issue #1465.
- [x] Code is [rebased](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/git/README.md#sync-your-local-repo) on `origin/master`.
- [x] Add tests that fail without your changes.
- [ ] N/A: Update all relevant [documentation](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/tree/master/docs).
  
  On Linux, it's common to use error stream (2) as an information stream.
  There is no errors in this case, it's just a way to report info.
  When PowerShell redirects error stream, it wraps all output from stream 2
  in NativeCommandError ErrorRecord and subsequent text in
  NativeCommandErrorMessage ErrorRecord. 
  
  That doesn't happen for interactive experience (when there is no
  redirection), but it shows up in logs, scripting and non-console
  powershell hosts (i.e. PowerShell ISE).
  
  Here we change the formatter, so we are keeping the ErrorRecords
  objects, but we are changing their default representation.
  
  If it's a NativeCommandError, we don't use the regular ErrorRecord
  formatter. It allows us keep ErrorRecord object,
  but in redirection case it will look exectly like on the screen.
  
  Also, we are change NativeCommandErrorMessage to use one line per
  ErrorRecord to enable this scenario.
  
  We also make the error stream messages show-up without red color.

cc @lzybkr @JamesWTruher @BrucePay
title: Error stream

body:
Per #1437 we should be able to compile DSC Configuration. It requires `function Configuration` from PSDesiredStateConfiguration.psm1 in **parse** time of configuration.

At the same time `PSDesiredStateConfiguration.psm1` has both parts: for compile time and for runtime. Bringing the whole module is possible, but undesirable solution, since it's a separate project.

~~Proposition: bring `PSDesiredStateConfiguration.psm1` as a post-build step.~~ 

Update: @johnkord figured out the layout of `contentFiles` in nuget package and is able to get the PSDSC module published to `publish\Modules` folder from the nuget package directly. The PSDSC nuget package has been checked in to psl-windows-build via https://github.com/PowerShell/psl-windows-build/pull/23. The same technique can be applied to the MAML work #1469

Remaining Tasks:
- [x] Update powershell-unix to depend on PSDSC.nupkg and libmi.nupkg; Update powershell-win-core to depend on PSDSC.nupkg
- [x] Add the unix configuration tests
- [ ] ~~Make the same configuration tests work for both unix and windows~~ (tracked by #1713)
title: DSC Configuration compilation requires PSDesiredStateConfiguration.psm1

For more information, see the about_Remote_Troubleshooting Help topic.
At line:1 char:6
- $s = nsn -ComputerName .
-      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

title: Use of SemanticVersion in $PSVersionTable Breaks Remoting

body:
## Steps to reproduce

$s = New-PSSession .
## Expected behavior

Creates a session
## Actual behavior

Fails to create a session
## Root Cause:

A new function pointer was added to System.Management.Automation.Remoting.WSManPluginEntryDelegates and WSManPluginEntryDelegatesInternal, but was not added to the corresponding unmanaged structure (PwrshPluginWkr_Ptrs) in pwrshplugindefs.h in the WinRM Plugin code. This led to a buffer overrun when the reverse PInvoke code copied an extra 8 bytes of data (the extra function pointer) beyond the end of the unmanaged structure. The fix is to add an extra pointer to the end of the unmanaged structure so that they become byte-for-byte aligned once more.
title: WSManPluginEntryDelegatesInternal.wsManPluginShutdownCallbackNative Broke Remoting Over WinRM

body: macOS, removing the PSReadLine module makes the console essentially nonfunctional. Up-arrow doesn't work, backspace doesn't work correctly. Additionally, note that the default PSReadLine coloring doesn't work well in the default Terminal color scheme (which is why I'd tried unloading PSReadLine to begin with). It's perhaps worth noting that Mac/Linux users tend to have a broader range of color schemes in their console window; assuming the traditional PowerShell dark blue will rarely hold out. I might suggest disabling coloring by default, if possible, and just stick with monocolor text using the console's defaults at the time.

labels.description: The issue is a duplicate.
labels.name: Resolution-Duplicate

title: Console generally dysfunctional without PSReadLine

It appears that although `[IO.Path]::PathSeparator` is correctly set to colon, the PSMODULEPATH is using semicolon:

I should be able to separate path variables using the PathSeparator, like I can on Windows:

```
PS > $Env:PSMODULEPATH -split [System.IO.Path]::PathSeparator
C:\Users\Joel\OneDrive\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules
C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules
C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Modules
C:\Users\Joel\Projects\Modules
```
## Actual behavior

```
PS > $Env:PSMODULEPATH -split [System.IO.Path]::PathSeparator

/root/.local/share/powershell/Modules;;/opt/microsoft/powershell/Modules
```

body:
From psmvp list

> is there any plan to support gnus-style double hyphen parameter parsing on *nix? It seems there's already some leeway there for environment specific tweaks (if reading through the github issues list is taken into account.) What am I talking about? Well, how fully specified arguments for gnu utils are provided like --debug (double), but can be abbreviated as -d (single). Is there room to update the binder to support both -debug and --debug? (for example.) I can't see that being a breaking change, but it might be a nice spot of grease to ease the muscle memory.

body:
<!--

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](../docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
## Steps to reproduce

``` powershell
powershell -Noprofile -Command '"[Console]::Error.Write(""""foo"""")"'
```
## Expected behavior

This is inbox windows v5.1 behavior

```
PS C:\> $powershell = Join-Path -Path $PsHome -ChildPath "powershell"
PS C:\> & $powershell -Noprofile -Command '"[Console]::Error.Write(""""foo"""")"'
fooPS C:\>
```
## Actual behavior

"where are quotes around `foo`"?

```
PS /Users/vors/dev/PowerShell> $powershell = Join-Path -Path $PsHome -ChildPath "powershell"                                                 
PS /Users/vors/dev/PowerShell> & $powershell -Noprofile -Command '"[Console]::Error.Write(""""foo"""")"'                                     
At line:1 char:24                                                                                                                            
+ [Console]::Error.Write(foo)                                                                                                                
+                        ~                                                                                                                   Missing ')' in method call.                                                                                                                 
 At line:1 char:24                                                                                                                            + [Console]::Error.Write(foo)                                                                                                                
+                        ~~~
Unexpected token 'foo' in expression or statement.
At line:1 char:27
+ [Console]::Error.Write(foo)
+                           ~
Unexpected token ')' in expression or statement.
    + CategoryInfo          : ParserError: (:) [], ParentContainsErrorRecordException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : MissingEndParenthesisInMethodCall

```
## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value                                                                                                        
----                           -----                                                                                                        
PSVersion                      5.1.10032.0                                                                                                  
PSEdition                      PowerShellCore                                                                                               
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}                                                                                      
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0                                                                                                      
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.7                                                                                               
CLRVersion                                                                                                                                  
WSManStackVersion              3.0                                                                                                          
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3                                                                                                          
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```

body:
<!--

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](../docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
## Steps to reproduce

``` powershell
powershell -c {[console]::Error.Write('abc')} 2>&1`
```
## Expected behavior

```
powershell : abc
At line:1 char:6
+ $q = powershell -c "[console]::Error.Write('abc')" 2>&1
+      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (abc:String) [], RemoteException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NativeCommandError
```
## Actual behavior

```
powershell : Cannot process the XML from the 'Error' stream of
'C:\WINDOWS\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe': Data at the root level is invalid. Line 1, position 1.
At line:1 char:1
+ powershell -c {[console]::Error.Write('abc')} 2>&1
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : SyntaxError: (C:\WINDOWS\Syst...\powershell.exe:String) [], XmlException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : ProcessStreamReader_CliXmlError
```
## Environment data

This repros on Full Framework build and on inbox PS v5.1 on Windows.

body:
This is post-mortem task for #1570

PowerShell uses Assemlby.GetTypes() in few places
One of them is [tab-completion](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/6d0396484e901745df4a567c4a8d8b5407529329/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/CommandCompletion/CompletionCompleters.cs#L5867).

The problem that required revert in #1570 was the fact that we were trying to call `Assemlby.GetType()` on assembly with misformed internal type. The type used [FieldOffset](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.runtime.interopservices.fieldoffsetattribute%28v=vs.110%29.aspx) incorrectly and caused problems when loading **this internal type**.

As far as auto-completion concerns, this should not result in the fatal inability to complete types.

cc @BrucePay @lzybkr @LeeHolmes

labels.description: core PowerShell engine, interpreter, and runtime
labels.name: WG-Engine

labels.description: The issue is fixed.
labels.name: Resolution-Fixed

title: Consider guard calls to Assembly.GetTypes() in tab-completion (and maybe other places)

body:
Resolves #1431.

Setting custom key bindings for things like `"` now works.

This PR specifically fixes the comparison and display of keys; it _does not_ address the fact that we have some incorrect key definitions for Linux (due to limitations of System.Console), which will need to be addressed in the future.

@lzybkr please review 😄 

Where `$masterkeys` is `Get-PSReadLineKeyHandler` for the master branch, and `$charkeys` is for this feature branch, here is the diff of the two for the key property (note that the function property diff was empty).

``` powershell
> Compare-Object $masterkeys $charkeys -Property key                                                                                                                                                                               
key                 SideIndicator
---                 -------------
Ctrl+Shift+D2       =>           
Ctrl+Shift+OemMinus =>           
Ctrl+Oem6           =>           
Ctrl+Alt+Oem6       =>           
Alt+B               =>           
Alt+F               =>           
Ctrl+Alt+Shift+Oem2 =>           
Ctrl+              <=           
Ctrl+              <=           
Ctrl+              <=           
Ctrl+Alt+          <=           
Alt+Shift+B         <=           
Alt+Shift+F         <=           
Ctrl+Alt+          <=           
```

The keys with missing characters following the `+` are from the master branch, where they are not displayed correctly as they are special keys. For instance:

``` powershell
> $charkeys | where { $_.Key -eq "Ctrl+Shift+D2" }                                                      

Key           Function Description                    
---           -------- -----------                    
Ctrl+Shift+D2 SetMark  Mark the location of the cursor


> $masterkeys | where { $_.Function -eq "SetMark" }                                                     

Key          Function Description                    
---          -------- -----------                    
Ctrl+       SetMark  Mark the location of the cursor
Alt+Spacebar SetMark  Mark the location of the cursor
```

So SetMark is bound to `Ctrl+@`. While `Ctrl+@` would be the best thing to display, we currently display `Ctrl+`, and this fixes it to at least show correctly (if not the most clearly) `Ctrl+Shift+D2`.

Another instance:

``` powershell
> $charkeys | where { $_.Key -eq "Ctrl+Shift+OemMinus" }                                                

Key                 Function Description         
---                 -------- -----------         
Ctrl+Shift+OemMinus Undo     Undo a previous edit


> $masterkeys | where { $_.Function -eq "Undo" }                                                        

Key           Function Description         
---           -------- -----------         
Ctrl+        Undo     Undo a previous edit
Ctrl+X,Ctrl+U Undo     Undo a previous edit
```

This brings us to the point of `OemMinus` not being the correct key on Linux (`System.Console`'s Linux implementation will never provide a key with `OemMinus`). However, this is a big enough problem that it merits a separate set of changes to rectify (all the key definitions need to be manually reconciled with the Linux implementation of `System.Console`).

Finally, this fixes the display of the `Alt+B` binding, which was previously being incorrectly displayed as `Alt+Shift+B`.

labels.description: PSReadline related issues
labels.name: WG-Interactive-PSReadLine

title: Fix PSReadLine custom key binding on Linux

body:
We have a test for `$input` type behavior in advanced functions (functions that are cmdlets).

``` powershell
It '$input Type should be enumerator' {
        function from_begin { [cmdletbinding()]param() begin { Write-Output -NoEnumerate $input } }
        function from_process { [cmdletbinding()]param() process { Write-Output -NoEnumerate $input } }
        function from_end { [cmdletbinding()]param() end { Write-Output -NoEnumerate $input } }

        (from_begin) -is [System.Collections.IEnumerator] | Should Be $true
        (from_process) -is [System.Collections.IEnumerator] | Should Be $true
        (from_end) -is [System.Collections.IEnumerator] | Should Be $true
    } 
```

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/b731549a198c538d0e5e3ca4c50183f988b5f7e2/test/powershell/Language/Parser/AutomaticVariables.Tests.ps1#L3

This tests works fine in PS v2. Since then, the behavior changed to this

``` powershell
        (from_begin) -is [System.Collections.ArrayList] | Should Be $true
        (from_process) -is [System.Collections.ArrayList] | Should Be $true
        (from_end) -is [System.Object[]] | Should Be $true
```

Which is pretty inconsistent, but exists since v3.

@lzybkr was trying to fix it (back to v2 behavior) and it broke a couple customer scenarios.

Plan: we will gover feedback about this issue and may consider go thru breaking change process.
Meanwhile, I'm marking the test as `-Skip`

body:
There is more that I would like to change, but knowing the speed at which our docs are updated, I would like to submit this as a first pass.

The readme is mostly rewritten, with a helpful table for getting PowerShell (packages, installation, building, and test status). The PowerShell description of COM and WMI did not make much sense for cross-platform PowerShell; I'd like @joeyaiello's help to come up with an improved description. I removed the TODOs as they should instead be tracked by issues (and not in the readme on the master branch).

I fixed a few docs folders where eponymous documents were turned into readmes so that browsing the folders on GitHub is more readable. My goal will be to have a readme for every folder.

We really need to consolidate our submodule notes; they've become spread far and wide, but I'd like to do this separately.

/cc @vors @joeyaiello @jianyunt

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.

```
Start-Process -NoNewWindow powershell
```

Run process in a new window
## Actual behavior

Run process in the same window, but UX is broken

```
PS /Users/vors> Start-Process -NoNewWindow powershell                                                                                        
PS /Users/vors> 14;1Rl                                                                                                                       
14pyright (C) 2016 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
1Rl : The term '1Rl' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable program. Check the spelling of the name, 
or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
At line:1 char:4
+ 14;1Rl
+    ~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (1Rl:String) [], CommandNotFoundException
```

Repros on OS X, Linux and Windows

body:
This may have something to do with PSReadline on Linux since remote debugging works correctly in the other direction (Windows -> Linux).
## Steps to reproduce
1.  Set up Windows machine and Linux VM for SSH remoting (see docs).
2.  Create interactive session from Linux -> Windows
    Enter-PSSession -HostName <WindowsHost> -UserName <username>
3.  Set breakpoint in script on windows machine and run in remote session.
   Set-PSBreakpoint test.ps1 -line 12
   test.ps1
4.  After debugger stops type a debugger command at the prompt
   [WindowsHost] PS C: />> list
## Expected behavior

Expect debugger command to work.
## Actual behavior

Command prompt hangs
## Environment data
title: Linux -> Windows remote debugging does not work

body:
When establishing a connection for an SSH remote session, if a transport error occurs during Runspace.Open(), that error is ignored and the client waits until a one minute connection time out occurs.  PowerShell throws an "SSH.exe process not created" exception but this exception doesn't get propagated and the connection attempt wait continues until connection timeout occurs.
## Steps to reproduce
1.  Set up SSH based remoting on a Windows machine (see docs)
2.  Try to create a session using an invalid user or host name.
   $session = New-PSSession -HostName <BadName> -UserName <username>
## Expected behavior

When ssh.exe fails to make the connection PowerShell should propagate the exception and quit New-PSSession while displaying the error.
## Actual behavior

PowerShell New-PSSession Cmdlet appears to continue waiting for a connection (or appears hung) until the one minute connection timeout occurs that finally allows New-PSSession to quit with error.
## Environment data

Name                           Value

---

PSVersion                      5.1.10032.0
PSEdition                      WindowsPowerShell
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
GitCommitId                    v0.6.0-376-g87ae333f7d3c7727c60369f086aa3dfe9a6bc176-dirty
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1

labels.description: The issue is fixed.
labels.name: Resolution-Fixed

title: SSH based remoting does not handle errors during connection attempt

body:
AppVeyor builds fail due to reporting the progress of script analysis, specifically [this piece of code](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/commit/b400ba368811ac0221632457669dff5203940616#diff-8db7ab7b17a956849fe85734af72f5bbR1327). Removing the `CORECLR` guard results in this error:

> The running command stopped because the preference variable "ErrorActionPreference" or common parameter is set to Stop: Cannot process the XML from the 'Error' stream of 'C:\projects\powershell\src\powershell-windows\bin\Debug\netcoreapp1.0\win81-x64\publish\powershell.exe': Data at the root level is invalid. Line 1, position 382.

As can be seen in [this build](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/PowerShell/powershell/build/0.6.0.3806).

@lzybkr notes that disabling the code is not enough:

> By not calling WriteProgress with a Completed message, we'll leave screen artifacts. See the corresponding call in SriptAnalysis.cs, line 43 - that code is not guarded at all by #if !CORECLR
> 
> I don't have a strong preference on this specific progress message, but if progress messages are causing problems in CI, turning them off this way is not the right fix.

labels.description: Issue has been identified as a bug in the product
labels.name: Issue-Bug

body:
<!--

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](../docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
## Steps to reproduce

``` powershell
$VerbosePreference = 'Continue'
$PWD.Drive
```
## Expected behavior

```
Name Used (GB) Free (GB) Provider   Root CurrentLocation
---- --------- --------- --------   ---- ---------------
C       219.04     17.90 FileSystem C:\    Users\jasonsh
```
## Actual behavior

```
VERBOSE: Perform operation 'Query CimInstances' with following parameters, ''queryExpression' = SELECT * FROM Win32_LogicalDisk WHERE DeviceId='C:','queryDialect' = WQL,'namespaceName' =
```

body:
This function is required for PSRP on Linux, as we need to wrap the call into WSManPluginManagedEntryWrapper.InitPlugin such that it is invoked via reflection from an assembly loaded with our custom context.

This fixes PSRP from Linux to Windows.

/cc @daxian-dbw @paulcallen
title: Add WSManPluginWrapper to AssemblyLoadContext

body:
These changes add support for PowerShell remoting over SSH.  This includes creating new transport objects to use SSH as the PSRP remoting transport along with a new parameter set for the New-PSSession, Invoke-Command, and Enter-PSSession cmdlets.  The parameters are HostName, UserName, and KeyPath to allow both SSH password prompt (for interactive sessions) and key based user authentication.

This check in is to support PowerShell SSH remoting demos and the final parameter sets will likely change in the future.  I also have a list of known issues that will be added to this GitHub repo.

The changes affect Win32 full, core, and Linux versions.  For Linux some types such as WindowsIdentity information were left null.  Also the crypto helper that is based on Win32 native APIs is abandoned for Linux since SSH provides the encrypt/decrypt.

PowerShell SSH remoting requires SSH to be installed on both client (ssh.exe) and server (sshd.exe) along with a PowerShell build including these changes.  In addition the server (sshd.exe) configuration must include the ability to launch a PowerShell subsystem in server mode, and I'll add a new document to describe how to do this.
title: Add PowerShell remoting over SSH feature

body:
## Steps to reproduce

From powershell build on windows, try to open `.\powershell.sln` (from the root of the repo)

```
> .\powershell.sln
>  invoke-item .\powershell.sln
```
## Expected behavior

Opening sln file will launch Visual Studio, like inbox powershell does.
## Actual behavior

```
PS F:\dev\PowerShell> .\powershell.sln
Cannot run a document in PowerShell Core: F:\dev\PowerShell\powershell.sln.
At line:1 char:1
+ .\powershell.sln
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (F:\dev\PowerShell\powershell.sln:String) [], RuntimeException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : CantActivateDocumentInPowerShellCore

PS F:\dev\PowerShell> invoke-item .\powershell.sln
invoke-item : Operation is not supported on this platform.
At line:1 char:1
+ invoke-item .\powershell.sln
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [Invoke-Item], PlatformNotSupportedException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : System.PlatformNotSupportedException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.InvokeItemCommand

```
## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSEdition                      PowerShellCore
PSVersion                      5.1.10032.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
GitCommitId                    v0.6.0-371-ge79a183994cca92319db8ab5d5188b48717a68d7-dirty
CLRVersion
WSManStackVersion              3.0
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```

labels.name: Resolution-Duplicate

title: invoke-item doesn't work on windows (Cannot open sln file from powershell)
